comments: Primitively but not imprimitively represented by x^2+y^2.The disjoint union of {1}, A003654, and A031398. - _Max Alekseyev_, Mar 09 2010It appears that a(n) is the n-th index, k, such that f(k) = 2, where f(k) = 3*(Sum_{i=1..k} floor(i^2/k)) - k^2 (see A175908). - _John W. Layman_,  May 16 2011Squarefree numbers with no prime factors of the form 4k+3. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, May 17 2011Squarefree members of A202057. - _Artur Jasinski_, Dec 10 2011
links: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
S. R. Finch, On a Generalized Fermat-Wiles Equation
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
formula: a(n) ~ k*n*sqrt(log n), where k = 2.1524249... = A013661/A064533. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 20 2015
mathematica: lim = 17; t = Join[{1}, Select[Union[Flatten[Table[x^2 + y^2, {x, lim}, {y, x}]]], # < lim^2 && SquareFreeQ[#] &]]
prog: (PARI) is(n)=my(f=factor(n)); for(i=1,#f~,if(f[i,2]>1 || f[i,1]%4==3, return(0))); 1 \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 20 2015(Haskell)a020893 n = a020893_list !! (n-1)a020893_list = filter (\x -> any (== 1) $ map (a010052 . (x -)) $                             takeWhile (<= x) a000290_list) a005117_list-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 28 2015
